reasoning: The critique targets the moral-uncertainty move that could, in principle, bolster the essay’s “fussy in practice even under uncertainty” upshot; that’s a meaningful but not necessary pillar for the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion (which is also supported by the earlier fragility/product-of-factors and value-function fussiness arguments). So centrality is moderate. Substantively, it correctly notes that intertheoretic aggregation/normalization choices can flip recommendations in the essay’s own toy examples and that a robust, representation-invariant dominance claim is not shown. However, it overstates the essay’s commitment: the original text already emphasizes thorniness, shows disagreement between methods, and hedges conclusions, so the critique is partly ‘priced in’. The proposed alternative normalization (“action-guidingness under bounded rationality / realistically reachable outcome set”) is under-specified and not argued to be independently plausible or to systematically favor easygoing views, reducing refutational force. Overall, it raises a real conditionality/robustness challenge to one strand of the argument, but doesn’t strongly undermine the main thesis.
title: Intertheoretic comparison method choice determines whether fussy views dominate
